Geography: tropical and subtropical areas of Asia: India, Indo-China, southern part of China, the island of Taiwan
Properties: dong kui zi: bitter, cold, laxative
冬葵子: 甘，寒，滑 (sweet, cold, slippery)
Meridians: dong kui zi: large intestine, small intestine, bladder
Maladies Treated: dong kui zi (Malva crispa L; Malva verticillata, L.): urinary tract infection, edema, constipation, dysentery, gonorrhea, boils, bronchitis, cystitis, cataract, blocked urination and constipation, gonorrhea with painful urination, breast swelling and pain in women, insufficient lactation, red and white dysentery, boils, eye opacity
qing ma zi (Abutilon theophrasti Medic): urinary tract infection, edema
Medical Function: dong kui zi: clears heat, promoting urination to drain dampness, detoxifies, reduces edema, promotes lactation and alleviates breast swelling and pain (human use)
qing ma zi: clears and drains damp heat, reduces edema

dong kui zi and sha ren equal parts, ground into powder, taken with hot wine, dosage 3 qian (about 9-12g), used to treat swelling and pain in a woman’s vaginal area; swelling resolves following intake
Samples of Formulae: pai shi fang (expelling stone formula): application for kidney stones with urinary tract infection. Composition: hua shi, jin qian cao 30g each, dong kui zi, hai jin sha 15g each, bian xu, ju mai, raw ji nei jin, che qian zi 12g each, wang bu liu xing 10g, niu xi, chuan lian zi 9g each, mu tong, gan cao 6g each. Mu Tong may be omitted, because one might mistakenly purchase Guan Mu Tong, which is toxic. Preparation: herbs decocted in water, one dose per day. Functions include clearing heat, draining dampness, unblocking painful urinary dysfunction, and expelling stones.
Contraindications: Not to be used in cases of qi deficiency, spleen deficiency (pixu), loose stools, or pregnancy.
Notes: dong kui zi (Malva crispa L; or Malva verticillata, L.) and qing ma zi (Abutilon theophrasti Medic) are two different herbs with different functions; do not interchange. Currently, the dong kui zi sold commercially are mainly seeds of qing ma (Abutilon theophrasti Medic.). The herb sold as dong kui zi in Taiwan markets is also mainly the seed of qing ma.

Maladies Treated: urethral infection (orally, especially when urine is acidic)
epilepsy (grand mal and persistent forms, ineffective for frontal lobe epilepsy patients; orally, combined with phenytoin, Vitamin D, calcium gluconate)
vaginal fungal infection (topically, combined with borneol and cold cream)
lower back pain and stiff neck (topically applied in inner canthus area, ineffective for protruding disc and lumbar spine injury)
knee sprain (topically applied in inner canthus, opposite side)
Medical Function: weak alkaline properties—can inhibit microorganisms including Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus anthracis, Freund Shigella, Shigella dysentery bacillus, typhoid bacillus, paratyphoid bacillus, Proteus, Staphylococcus aureus, Candida albicans (plate method, medium containing 10% borax). Borax can inhibit diphtheria bacillus, brucellosis, pneumococcal, meningococcal, hemolytic streptococcus (paper disc method)
Available to flush ulcers, abscesses, especially mucosal inflammation, such as conjunctivitis, gastritis, etc.
cleans and makes mucosal surfaces alkaline; orally for urethral sterilization, especially if urine is acidic

Detoxification and antisepsis
Dosage: Internal usage: pills or powder form, 0.5-1 qian (approx. 1.5-3 gram); external usage: very finely powdered borax for topical sprinkle or paste
Samples of Formulae: Treatment of epilepsy: Take peng sha (borax) orally. For sparse episodes, use 0.3 g each time, 3 times a day. For frequent seizures, use 0.5 g each time, 3 times a day. For grand mal or persistent cases, use 1 g daily. Use peng sha in conjunction with phenytoin, vitamin D, and calcium adjuvant therapy. For persistent epilepsy patients, besides using peng sha, also use 10% calcium gluconate 1 g, 2 times a day intravenously. Discontinue after symptoms are under control. Medication for a course is three months. From the second course of treatment, discontinue phenytoin. Do not discontinue phenytoin before the start of the peng sha (borax) treatments. Otherwise, it may frequently lead to grand mal or persistent seizures. If other anti-epileptic drugs have been used before the application of peng sha (borax), when switching to the peng sha (borax) treatment, alternate the use of peng sha and the drug. Then gradually phase out the original drug. Otherwise, if using peng sha (borax) alone, increase the dosage of peng sha to double. Result: 10 cases—9 cases of grand mal patients, one case was a sustained attack patient. All patients were in long-term use of different epilepsy drugs and could not control their recurrence. After treatment by the method described above, all cases were significantly effective in the first course of treatment and significantly reduced the number of attacks. The attacks showed only a few seconds of confusion and seemed to drop to a petit mal condition. Some patients showed only individual limb or mandible movement effects without loss of consciousness. After the second course of treatment, seven cases were able to completely control the onset of symptoms. Three cases were still having sparse small seizures or localized attacks. The majority of patients were taking the treatment for more than one year continuously, and there were no cases of adverse reactions or toxic reactions. This therapy is ineffective for frontal lobe epilepsy patients. For those with hepatorenal insufficiency, it is better not to use this therapy. Treatment of vaginal fungal infection: Composition of herb: Peng sha (borax) 97%, bing pian (borneol) 3%. Mix thoroughly; then add cold cream, about 50–60% of the total amount of the end product. Use a vaginal speculum to spread the vagina, and then smear the cream evenly around the wall of the vagina and vulva, once a day. Five days is a course of treatment. Result: Treatment of 144 cases. Follow-up examination: 82 cases. After one course of treatment in 59 cases, 50 cases were cured. After two courses in 17 cases, 16 cases were cured.After three courses in 6 cases, 3 cases were cured. The total cure rate was 84.1%. Treatment of lower back pain: Place peng sha (borax) on an iron pan. Heat the pan on a stove until peng sha becomes dry and powdery. Grind into a very fine powder. When applying, let the patient lie down supine. Pick a little calcined peng sha (borax) and apply it to the two inner canthi and to the yin jiao point. Lie quietly for 4–5 minutes. Let tears come out. Then let the patient bend down, turn the waist, and squat. Result: Treated more than 100 patients. In general, after treatment, pain was reduced. The majority recovered after 1–3 treatments. It was more effective when more tears came out. This method can also be used for stiff neck, but is ineffective in cases of protruding disc and lumbar spine injury. Knee Sprain. Name of formula: Peng sha san (borax powder). For treatment of knee sprain: Use a little finely processed borax powder at night before going to bed. Put it into the inner canthus (the angle formed by the meeting of the upper and lower eyelids at the inner side of the eye). If the left knee is sprained, treat the canthus of the right eye, and vice versa. Generally, one to three treatments will be effective. After applying the medication, tears may come out. [Zhejiang Journal of Traditional Chinese Medicine, 9(1): 24, 1966]
Contraindications: Careful use when orally administered. Do not use in patients with yinxu with fire condition. Temporary medicinal usage only, not for long-term internal consumption.
